text: Keep cleaning products locked away to prevent child poisoning.
Use childproof locks on cabinets containing sharp utensils.
Do not leave cooking unattended to avoid kitchen fires.
Install smoke detectors in all rooms and test monthly.
Cover electrical outlets to prevent shock in toddlers.
Wear helmets and gloves when working with heavy machinery.
Machines must have emergency stop buttons within reach.
Warning signs should be posted near all hazardous zones.
Employees must wear ear protection in high noise zones.
Forklift operators must be trained and licensed.
Install grab bars in bathrooms to prevent elderly falls.
Use non-slip mats near sinks and tubs for elder safety.
Ensure clear walking paths with no floor clutter.
Install night lights in hallways for nighttime safety.
Bedrails should be used in hospitals for elderly patients.
Avoid overloading electrical outlets with multiple devices.
Unplug appliances when not in use to prevent overheating.
Keep water away from electrical equipment.
Extension cords should not run under carpets.
Frayed wires must be replaced immediately.
Classroom scissors should have rounded tips for safety.
Science labs must store chemicals in locked cabinets.
Emergency exits must be clearly marked and accessible.
Teachers must supervise playground activity to prevent injuries.
Sharp tools like paper cutters should be locked away.
Seat belts must be worn at all times in moving vehicles.
Children should use car seats appropriate for their age and weight.
Motorcyclists must wear helmets approved by safety standards.
Pedestrians should cross roads only at marked crosswalks.
Avoid using mobile phones while driving or walking on roads.
